items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item: 8.02
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
								 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with ACE Charter High School  
					 
					 
On November 1, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from ACE Charter High School.  (“ACE”).  A copy of ACE’s original request is included.  Pursuant to the Charter Act and Title 5 of the California Code of regulations, section 11969.9, the District responded to ACE’s request for facilities and ADA projections.  
					 
On January 31, 2014, in accordance with the law and regulatory requirements, the District Administration submitted a preliminary proposal for facilities to ACE, offering facilities to ACE at Independence High School but subject to approval by the Board.  (A copy of the District’s January 31, 2014, Preliminary Proposal is included.).
					 
Staff has been in discussions with ACE regarding its facilities needs for the 2014-2015 school year.  On February 26, 2014, the District received ACE’s preliminary acceptance of the District’s facilities proposal, as modified by the parties’ discussion, for facilities at the Independence site.  A copy of ACE’s conditional acceptance is included.  The parties are generally not far apart, although some details and terms remain to be finalized.  Pursuant to the California Code of Regulations, the District must provide a final facilities offer to ACE on or before April 1, 2014.
					 
Since ACE has indicated its conditional acceptance of the Independence location, but the Board does not meet again before April 1, the Administration requests authority to negotiate and submit to ACE a final facilities offer for facilities at the Independence High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
					 
Funding Source:
Measures G, E and/or I; Capital Facilities Funds
					 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined.
					 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate with and submit to ACE a final facilities offer for facilities at the Independence High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form  (included herewith) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with Downtown College Prep Charter School  
	 
	 
On October 23, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from Downtown College Prep Charter School.  (“DCP”).  A copy of DCP’s original request is included.  Pursuant to the Charter Act and Title 5 of the California Code of regulations, section 11969.9, the District responded to DCP’s request for facilities and ADA projections. 
	 
On January 31, 2014, in accordance with the law and regulatory requirements, the District Administration submitted a preliminary proposal for facilities to DCP, offering facilities to DCP at Independence High School but subject to approval by the Board.  (A copy of the District’s January 31, 2014, Preliminary Proposal is included.).
	 
Staff has been in discussions with DCP regarding its facilities needs for the 2014-2015 school year.  On February 28, 2014, the District received DCP’s response to the District’s preliminary proposal in which DCP has informed the District that it “anticipates accepting the space that the District has offered.”  A copy of DCP’s response is included.  Some details and terms remain to be finalized between the parties.  Pursuant to the California Code of Regulations, the District must provide a final facilities offer to DCP on or before April 1, 2014.
	 
Since DCP has indicated it anticipates acceptance the Independence location offered, but the Board does not meet again before April 1, the Administration requests authority to negotiate and submit to DCP a final facilities offer for facilities at the Independence High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
	 
Funding Source:
Measures G, E and/or I; Capital Facilities Funds
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined.
	 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate with and submit to DCP a final facilities offer for facilities at the Independence High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form  (included herewith) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with Summit Public School: Rainier Charter School  
	 
	 
On November 1, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from Summit Public School: Rainier Charter School.  (“Rainier”).  A copy of Rainier’s original request is included.  Pursuant to the Charter Act and Title 5 of the California Code of regulations, section 11969.9, the District responded to Rainier’s request for facilities and ADA projections. 
	 
On January 31, 2014, in accordance with the law and regulatory requirements, the District Administration submitted a preliminary proposal for facilities to Rainier, offering facilities to Rainier at Mt. Pleasant High School but subject to approval by the Board.  (A copy of the District’s January 31, 2014, Preliminary Proposal is included.).
	 
On February 28, 2014, the District received Rainier’s preliminary conditional acceptance of the District’s preliminary proposal of substantially the current Mt. Pleasant location subject to certain specified modifications to the District’s January 31 facilities proposal, including exclusive use of the restroom facility and a portion of the basketball court area adjacent to the existing Rainier facilities, as shown on the attached Site Plan.  A copy of Rainier’s conditional acceptance is included.  The parties are in general agreement, although some details and terms remain to be finalized.  Pursuant to the California Code of Regulations, the District must provide a final facilities offer to Rainier on or before April 1, 2014.  
	 
Since Rainier has indicated its conditional acceptance of substantially the current Mt. Pleasant location (albeit subject to certain conditions remaining to be negotiated and finalized) but the Board does not meet again before April 1, the Administration requests authority to negotiate and submit to Rainier a final facilities offer for facilities at the Mt. Pleasant High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
	 
Funding Source:
Measures G, E and/or I; Capital Facilities Funds
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined.
	 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate with and submit to Rainier a final facilities offer for facilities at the Mt. Pleasant High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form  (included herewith) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item: 8.05
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with Summit Public School: Tahoma Charter School  
		 
		 
On November 1, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from Summit Public School: Tahoma Charter School.  (“Tahoma”).  A copy of Tahoma’s original request is included.  Pursuant to the Charter Act and Title 5 of the California Code of regulations, section 11969.9, the District responded to Tahoma’s request for facilities and ADA projections. 
		 
On January 31, 2014, in accordance with the law and regulatory requirements, the District Administration submitted a preliminary proposal for facilities to Tahoma, offering facilities to Tahoma at Yerba Buena High School but subject to approval by the Board.  (A copy of the District’s January 31, 2014, Preliminary Proposal is included.).
		 
On February 28, 2014, the District received Tahoma’s response to the District’s preliminary proposal.  In its response, Tahoma challenges the District’s projection of ADA, the location of the offered facilities (YBHS), the District’s comparison group of schools used as the basis of its preliminary proposal, the allocation of teaching stations, specialized classrooms and non-teaching space, the calculation of Tahoma’s pro rata share, and asserts that the facilities preliminarily offered are not reasonably equivalent to those in which the students would be accommodated if they were attending other district schools.  Tahoma has indicated, however, that if the District takes measures to address its concerns it may be amenable to accepting the District’s proposal.
		 
Pursuant to the California Code of Regulations, the District must provide a final facilities offer to Tahoma on or before April 1, 2014.  Staff is continuing to analyze and evaluate Tahoma’s response and will prepare a final offer for the YBHS site by the April 1, 2014, deadline.  The Board, however, does not meet again before April 1.  Therefore, the Administration requests authority to negotiate and submit to Tahoma a final facilities offer for facilities at the Yerba Buena High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
		 
Funding Source:
Measures G, E and/or I; Capital Facilities Funds
		 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined.
		 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate with and submit to Tahoma a final facilities offer for facilities at the Yerba Buena High School site, including a proposed Facilities Use Agreement in accordance with the District’s standard form  (included herewith) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item: 8.06
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
								 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Denial of Proposition 39 Facilities Request by Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter School  
					 
					 
On October 28, 2013, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2014-2015 school year from Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter School (“LVLA”) (then known as “Latino College Preparatory Academy II”).  A copy of LVLA’s original request is included.
  
Education Code section 47614(b) provides:
“Each school district shall make available, to each charter school operating in the school district, facilities sufficient for the charter school to accommodate all of the charter school's in-district students in conditions reasonably equivalent to those in which the students would be accommodated if they were attending other public schools of the district.  Facilities provided shall be contiguous, furnished, and equipped, and shall remain the property of the school district. The school district shall make reasonable efforts to provide the charter school with facilities near to where the charter school wishes to locate, and shall not move the charter school unnecessarily.”  
					 
The term “operating” is defined in section 47614(b)(5), which provides:
“The term ‘operating,’ as used in this section, shall mean either currently providing public education to in-district students, or having identified at least 80 in-district students who are meaningfully interested in enrolling in the charter school for the following year.”
					 
Section 11969.2 of the Regulations defines “in-district students” as used in Education Code section 47614(b), in pertinent part, as a student who is entitled to attend the schools of the District “and could attend a school district-operated school.”
					 
In support of its facilities request, LVLA submitted copies of twenty-seven (27) Intent to Enroll (“ITE”) forms for the 2014-2015 school year with the names of 32 separate identifiable potential students for its school.  However, thirteen (13) of the students identified in the ITE forms specify grade levels in 2014-2015 not served by the District and therefore do not qualify as “in-district” students within the meaning of Section 47614 or Regulation 11969.2.  In addition, one of the ITE forms was not signed by a parent.  On that basis, LVLA failed to meet the threshold of 80 in-district students pursuant to Education Code section 47614.
					 
Funding Source:
Not applicable.
					 
Fiscal Impact:
Not applicable.
					 
Recommendation: 
It is recommended for the reasons stated above, that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to approve the denial of Proposition 39 Facilities requested by Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.07
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding Draft of Local Control and Accountability Plan
	 
The text below was taken directly from the State approved LCAP template.
	 
The Local Control and Accountability Plan (LCAP) and annual update template shall be used to provide details regarding local educational agencies’ (LEAs) actions and expenditures to support pupil outcomes and overall performance pursuant to Education Code sections 52060, 52066, 47605, 47605.5, and 47606.5. 
For school districts, pursuant to Education Code section 52060, the LCAP must describe, for the school district and each school within the district, goals and specific actions to achieve those goals for all pupils and each subgroup of pupils identified in Education Code section 52052, including pupils with disabilities, for each of the state priorities and any locally identified priorities.
The LCAP is intended to be a comprehensive planning tool. LEAs may reference and describe actions and expenditures in other plans and funded by a variety of other fund sources when detailing goals, actions, and expenditures related to the state and local priorities. LCAPs must be consistent with school plans submitted pursuant to Education Code section 64001. The information contained in the LCAP, or annual update, may be supplemented by information contained in other plans (including the LEA plan pursuant to Section 1112 of Subpart 1 of Part A of Title I of Public Law 107-110) that are incorporated or referenced as relevant in this document.  
For each section of the template, LEAs should comply with instructions and use the guiding questions as prompts (but not limits) for completing the information as required by statute. 
State Priorities
The State priorities listed in Education Code sections 52060 and 52066 can be categorized as specified below for planning purposes, however, school districts and county offices of education must address each of the state priorities in their LCAP.
A. Conditions of Learning: 
Basic: degree to which teachers are appropriately assigned pursuant to Education Code section 44258.9, and fully credentialed in the subject areas and for the pupils they are teaching; pupils have access to standards-aligned instructional materials pursuant to Education Code section 60119; and school facilities are maintained in good repair pursuant to Education Code section 17002(d). (Priority 1)
Implementation of State Standards: implementation of academic content and performance standards adopted by the state board for all pupils, including English learners. (Priority 2)
Course access: pupil enrollment in a broad course of study that includes all of the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 7)
Expelled pupils (for county offices of education only): coordination of instruction of expelled pupils pursuant to Education Code section 48926.  (Priority 9)
Foster youth (for county offices of education only): coordination of services, including working with the county child welfare agency to share information, responding to the needs of the juvenile court system, and ensuring transfer of health and education records.  (Priority 10)
B. Pupil Outcomes: 
Pupil achievement: performance on standardized tests, score on Academic Performance Index, share of pupils that are college and career ready, share of English learners that become English proficient, English learner reclassification rate, share of pupils that pass Advanced Placement exams with 3 or higher, share of pupils determined prepared for college by the Early Assessment Program. (Priority 4)
Other pupil outcomes: pupil outcomes in the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Education Code section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 8)   
C. Engagement: 
Parent involvement: efforts to seek parent input in decision making, promotion of parent participation in programs for unduplicated pupils and special need subgroups.  (Priority 3)
Pupil engagement: school attendance rates, chronic absenteeism rates, middle school dropout rates, high school dropout rates, high school graduations rates. (Priority 5)
School climate: pupil suspension rates, pupil expulsion rates, other local measures including surveys of pupils, parents and teachers on the sense of safety and school connectedness. (Priority 6)

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-20 Mitigated Negative Declaration for the Stadium Lighting Project at Santa Teresa High School in Compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act
	 
The Board approved installation of stadium lighting at Santa Teresa High School February 14, 2013 (Board Item 11.03).  A necessary aspect of this project is compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA).  The primary purpose of CEQA is to inform decision makers of the environmental consequences of their actions through the completion of an initial study and environmental evaluation of potential impacts, and to identify any mitigation measures that will be employed.
	 
An Initial Study was prepared for the Santa Teresa Stadium Lighting Project, in conformance with the requirements of CEQA. On the basis of the Initial Study, the District has determined that the proposed project will not result in a significant effect on the environment because the mitigation and avoidance measures described in the Initial Study are included in the project.  The Mitigated Negative Declaration (MND - Attachment A) and Mitigation Monitoring or Reporting Program (MMRP - Attachment B) describes the mitigation and avoidance measures.
	 
Upon review of the MND and MMRP, the Board resolves to adopt a Mitigated Negative Declaration, stating that the environmental effects from the proposed project will not result in a significant effect on the environment. 
	 
Fiscal Impact
Not Applicable
	 
Funding Source
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/14-20 – Resolution to Adopt a Mitigated Negative Declaration for the Stadium Lighting Project at Santa Teresa High School in Compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Program Development Agreement with Chevron Energy Solution Company
	 
On November 17, 2011, the Board of Trustees approved a site improvement/deferred maintenance plan to be funded by Measure G bond proceeds in the amount of $32.5 million (Item 13.03). That plan included over $9 million of mechanical and electrical equipment repairs and/or replacements at all District sites. The California Clean Energy Jobs Act was created with the approval of Proposition 39 in the November 2012 statewide general election. Proposition 39 allocates projected revenue to the Clean Energy Job Creation Fund for five fiscal years, beginning with fiscal year 2013/14.  Under the initiative, roughly $550 million is annually available to be appropriated by the Legislature for eligible projects to improve energy efficiency and expand clean energy generation; roughly $5 million has been allocated to the District and another $1.5 million to charter schools housed in District facilities.  Some aging and/or failing mechanical and electrical system and controls components are not covered by the Measure G site improvement/deferred maintenance plan, and may not be eligible for Proposition 39 funding; those repairs could be covered using deferred maintenance funds. The Districtwide Energy Efficiency Project is funded by these combined funding sources.  
	 
Government Code Section 4217.10 – 4217.18 authorizes public agencies to enter into agreements with qualified energy services contract providers. However, before awarding an energy services contract, the Governing Board must first determine and find in a public hearing, that the net benefits of the energy conservation measures to be provided through the contract are greater than the expense of the contracted improvements. The authorizing Government Code section does not mandate a formal selection process; however, Administration deemed it prudent to solicit Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) from interested firms, to ensure transparency and allow the District to enter into a contract with a provider who offers the best value. On January 10, 2014, the District solicited Statements of Qualifications from highly qualified and experienced firms to design and construct cost effective energy performance improvements at District sites, including management of the associated Proposition 39 grant application process and compliance with all verification, benchmarking, reporting and other requirements defined by the California Energy Commission. The firms were required to meet these minimum requirements:
Accredited by the National Association of Energy Service Companies (NAESCO)
Included on the U.S. Department of Energy’s (DOE) Qualified List of Energy Service Companies
Successfully implemented at least five (5) energy performance contracts for the K-12 public sector of at least $5 million each in California in the last five (5) years
California B contractor license
Minimum of $15 million in bonding capacity for a single project
The solicitation delineated weighted selection criteria by which the firms would be evaluated. Three proposals were received on February 6, 2014. The qualifications of the three respondents were evaluated and scored. The final scores evidenced the quality and capacity of each of the respondents to bring value to the project:

Administration at this time requests approval of a Program Development Agreement pursuant to which chevron Energy Solutions will define the scope recommended of energy improvements and costs and net savings to the District from such work.
	 
Chevron Energy Solutions was found to offer the best overall value to the District in nearly every category, including proposed fees. Chevron Energy Solutions has enjoyed a very successful relationship with East Side on the solar photovoltaic, interior lighting and pool pump installations that have exceeded energy savings expectations. Chevron has successful experience working with local labor to better the community and under the requirements of the District’s Project Labor Agreement. Along with the facility improvements and energy conservation measures that will provide healthier learning environments and reduce energy and operational expenses, it is anticipated that 30 jobs will be created over the course of five years.  
	 
The California Conservation Corps (CCC) receives an allocation from the Clean Energy Job Creation Fund to perform energy surveys and other energy conservation-related activities for public schools. The CCC will conduct energy surveys to assess building conditions, identify energy efficiency opportunities, and establish baseline use at no cost to the District. The District applied for and was approved to receive these services.  Chevron Energy Services will work with CCC to coordinate this work, receive and utilize their survey results – providing the young adults and veterans that the CCC program serves with valuable work experience and training in the energy field.  
	 
Fiscal Impact:
Not to exceed $17.5 million
	 
Funding Source:
Measure G 
Proposition 39 Clean Energy Jobs Act funds
Deferred Maintenance funds
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to execute a Program Development Agreement with Chevron Energy Solutions Company to determine the specific energy conservation measures that will be used to support a proposed Energy Services Contract. Once it is determined through that process that the cost of the Energy Services Contract will be outweighed by the net savings provided through the improvements and energy conservation measures, those results and findings will be presented to the Board in accordance with the Government Code for the authorization to enter into and Energy Services Contract with Chevron Energy Solutions.

Discussion and/or Action Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2014-2015 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District. Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2014-2015 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District proposes the following areas for negotiations: total compensation which includes salary and benefits; contract language amendments to Articles 11, 14, 15, 18, 30, 31, Appendix M. The District also has an interest in ensuring that contract language is consistent with current funding formulas; eliminating references to COLA. The District seeks a three year agreement.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT

FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Award a Design-Build Contract for Swimming Pool Modernizations
	 
	 
	 
Background
On November 17, 2011, the Board of Trustees approved a site improvement/deferred maintenance plan, to be funded by Measure G Bond proceeds in the amount of $32.5 million (Item 13.03). That plan included swimming pool upgrades at eight (8) sites: Independence, Yerba Buena, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant and W.C. Overfelt High Schools, budgeted at $5.23 million. The intent of the project was to perform basic repairs as delineated in the 2004 Facilities Master Plan. 
	 
On May 10, 2012, the Board of Trustees awarded the design professional services contract for the Swimming Pool Modernizations project to Arch Pac Aquatics (Item 16.05). Arch Pac Aquatics developed drawings and specifications approved by the Division of the State Architect (DSA) for modernization of the pools at Independence High School.  The swimming pools at Independence High School were modernized as a stand-alone project, which was completed in July 2013.
	 
The Board of Trustees, pursuant to Education Code §17250.20, adopted Resolution #2012/2013-26 on March 21, 2013, to approve use of the design-build delivery method for the Swimming Pool Modernizations project affecting the remaining seven (7) school sites (Item 15.03).
	 
Design-Build Entity (DBE) Selection Criteria
The Request for Proposal (RFP) specified that the following criteria were to be considered in selecting the DBE whose proposal demonstrated the “best value” to the District, as defined in Education Code §17250.15. The “best value” basis of evaluation allows the District to select a DBE based on more than price alone, one of the advantages of design-build in comparison to traditional delivery methods. The first five (5) criteria are required by Education Code §17250.25, the Code section under which this design-build project is to be awarded. The additional criteria, which are critical to the success of the project, were added at the District’s discretion.
    
   
1.

100 points
	 
	 
District Review Panel
Recognizing the importance of early input by site staff and end users, a District review panel was established to assist in the DBE selection process. This review panel consisted of the Subject Area Coordinator for Health and Physical Education, a delegate from each of the 7 pool sites, swimming pool and boiler maintenance technicians, Capital Purchasing and Facilities staff, and the Blach Construction management team. 
	 
Proposal Scoring
The District received proposals from two DBEs. Based on the proposal evaluation criteria described above, the final score for each DBE is as follows:

The review panel unanimously agreed that Gonsalves & Stronck Construction Company, Inc. (G&S) provided a proposal that offers the best value to the District. The panel also concluded that additional investigation with G&S of pool design configurations is warranted. By awarding a programming and schematic design contract to G&S, they will meet with school site and district staff to further refine their proposed designs and associated pricing. This activity will transpire in late March and April, allowing District administration to carry forth to the Board in May a recommendation of contract amendment to finalize design and proceed with construction.

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve award of the programming and schematic design scope of a design-build contract for the Swimming Pool Modernizations Project to Gonsalves & Stronck Construction Company, Inc., in an amount not to exceed $276,564.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Recommendation for the Addition to the Current List of Architectural Firms for the Measures E, G, and I Capital Improvement Program
	 
In November 2000, California Proposition 35, also known as the Public Works Projects Act of 2000, was approved by California voters. The Act requires public entities like East Side Union High School District to qualify architectural firms prior to retaining them for professional services.  The District requires architectural firms to meet the following criteria:
California licensing or registry (for architects and engineers)
Successful experience with the Division of the State Architect
Successful experience on educational projects, particularly K-12
Successful experience in projects similar to the District’s renovation and new construction projects
Record of responsiveness
Acceptable business practices, such as discipline coordination, cost estimating, cost management, quality control, project team communications, dispute resolution, etc.
Resumes of key personnel
Litigation history
Competitive fee schedule
	 
The District released a Request for Qualifications for Architectural Services on December 19, 2013 (RFQ-08-13-14). The RFQ was advertised in local publications on December 26, 2013 and again on January 2, 2014, supplemented by staff’s outreach efforts to over forty (40) architectural firms whose portfolio of work includes similar projects. 
	 
Nineteen (19) Statements of Qualification (SOQ) were received on January 24, 2014. The SOQs were reviewed and scored by the Capital Purchasing Department using the weighted criteria delineated in the RFQ. SOQs were also reviewed by Facilities Planning staff who concurred with the assigned scores.  
	 
Based on this evaluation, Administration is recommending that the following firms be added to the existing pool of firms who are qualified to provide architectural services:  
ANLA Associates, Inc.
Artik Art & Architecture
ATI Architects & Engineers
Carducci & Associates, Inc.
Deems Lewis McKinley Architecture
Dougherty + Dougherty Architects, LLP
Gates + Associates
Gould Evans, Inc.
Hamilton + Aitken Architects
Hibser Yamauchi Architects
K2A Architecture + Interiors
LCA Architects
LPA, Inc.
McKim Design Group
MVE Institutional, Inc.
Quattrocchi Kwok Architects
tBP/Architecture, Inc.
Vallier Design Associates, Inc.
Vaughn Williams Architecture + Planning
	 
The firms who were deemed qualified to provide architectural services in June 2008 will remain in the qualified pool.  Capital Purchasing staff confirmed that their licenses are in good standing:
Aedis Architects
IBI Group (formerly BFGC)
Cody Anderson Wasney
Facilities Management, Planning & Operations
HMC Architects
NTD Architects
Perkins & Will
Spencer Associates
Sugimura Finney Architects
Verde Design
WLC Architects
	 
It is in the District’s best interest to allow interested architectural firms to join the pool over time, and to actively expand the pool to also include firms who provide design services in engineering disciplines (structural, mechanical, electrical, civil, etc.), as well as other types of professional service providers whose services are critical to a successful construction program (e.g., commissioning).  Administration will bring forth to the Board of Trustees on a quarterly basis (as needed) recommendations to add qualified professional service providers to the pool.
	 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Applicable
	 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the addition of the listed nineteen (19) firms to the pool of firms qualified to provide architectural services.

Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
	 
				A
				B
				C
				D
				E
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

SUBJECT:

On June 27, 2013 (Board Item 16.13), the Board awarded a construction contract in the amount of $3,003,800.00 to Zolman Construction & Development, Inc. (see Attachment A).
	 
On January 16, 2014 (Board Item 15.02), the Board approved change order #1 to add additional amount to cover unforeseen conditions in an amount not to exceed $170,000.00 (Attachment B).
